sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1:
Suppose you have data that represents the temperature in degrees Celsius at different times throughout a day, as shown in the table below:

| Time (hours) | Temperature (Celsius) |
| --- | --- |
| 0 | 10 |
| 2 | 15 |
| 4 | 20 |
| 6 | 25 |
| 8 | 30 |
| 10 | 35 |
| 12 | 28 |
| 14 | 25 |
| 16 | 22 |
| 18 | 19 |
| 20 | 16 |
| 22 | 13 |

Using Lagrange interpolation, estimate the temperature at 5 hours and 15 hours. Additionally, use Lagrange extrapolation to estimate the temperature at 24 hours.
message_2:
To estimate the temperature at 5 hours and 15 hours using Lagrange interpolation, we can use a subset of the data points to create a polynomial that fits the data. We will use the 4 closest data points for each estimation.

For 5 hours, we will use the data points at 2, 4, 6, and 8 hours:

| Time (hours) | Temperature (Celsius) |
| --- | --- |
| 2 | 15 |
| 4 | 20 |
| 6 | 25 |
| 8 | 30 |

For 15 hours, we will use the data points at 12, 14, 16, and 18 hours:

| Time (hours) | Temperature (Celsius) |
| --- | --- |
| 12 | 28 |
| 14 | 25 |
| 16 | 22 |
| 18 | 19 |

The Lagrange interpolation formula is:

L(x) = sum(y_i * l_i(x)) for i = 0 to n

where l_i(x) = product((x - x_j) / (x_i - x_j)) for j = 0 to n, j ≠ i

For 5 hours:

l_0(5) = ((5-4)*(5-6)*(5-8))/((2-4)*(2-6)*(2-8)) = 0.1667
l_1(5) = ((5-2)*(5-6)*(5-8))/((4-2)*(4-6)*(4-8)) = 0.6667
l_2(5) = ((5-2)*(5-4)*(5-8))/((6-2)*(6-4)*(6-8)) = 0.6667
l_3(5) = ((5-2)*(5-4)*(5-6))/((8-2)*(8-4)*(8-6)) = 0.1667

L(5) = 15 * 0.1667 + 20 * 0.6667 + 25 * 0.6667 + 30 * 0.1667 = 22.5

For 15 hours:

l_0(15) = ((15-14)*(15-16)*(15-18))/((12-14)*(12-16)*(12-18)) = 0.1667
l_1(15) = ((15-12)*(15-16)*(15-18))/((14-12)*(14-16)*(14-18)) = 0.6667
l_2(15) = ((15-12)*(15-14)*(15-18))/((16-12)*(16-14)*(16-18)) = 0.6667
l_3(15) = ((15-12)*(15-14)*(15-16))/((18-12)*(18-14)*(18-16)) = 0.1667

L(15) = 28 * 0.1667 + 25 * 0.6667 + 22 * 0.6667 + 19 * 0.1667 = 23.5

For 24 hours, we will use extrapolation with the same data points as for 15 hours:

L(24) = 28 * (-0.5) + 25 * 2 + 22 * (-1.5) + 19 * 1 = 8

So, the estimated temperature at 5 hours is 22.5°C, at 15 hours is 23.5°C, and at 24 hours is 8°C using Lagrange interpolation and extrapolation.
